choices.text: USG can be used for screening of DDH and alpha angle is increased
X-ray can be used for screening of DDH and alpha angle is increased
USG can be used for screening of DDH and alpha angle is decreased
USG can be used for screening of DDH and beta angle is decreased

questions.text: A young mother brings her 5 month old baby with complaints of clicking on the left hip while trying to wear clothes and the child not actively using the left limb. Choose the correct statement.
questions.solution:
Important Radiological Parameters in Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH)

1.Acetabular Index (AI)

  • Definition: The acetabular index is the angle formed by Hilgenreiner's line and a line from a point on the lateral triradiate cartilage to the lateral margin of the acetabulum.
  • Normal Range: In children older than 6 months, the AI should be less than 25°.
  • Imaging Modality: X-ray.
  • Significance: An increased acetabular index indicates insufficient acetabular development, a key feature in diagnosing DDH.

2. Alpha (α) Angle

  • Definition: The alpha angle is formed by the intersection of the baseline (along the ilium) and the acetabular roof line.
  • Normal Range: Greater than 60°. (Option A,B)
  • Imaging Modality: Ultrasound (USG). (Option C)
  • Significance: A smaller alpha angle suggests a shallow acetabulum, indicating hip dysplasia.

3. Beta (β) Angle

  • Definition: The beta angle is formed by the intersection of the baseline (along the ilium) and the inclination line (along the labrum).
  • Normal Range: Less than 55°. (Option D)
  • Imaging Modality: Ultrasound (USG).
  • Significance: A larger beta angle may indicate hip instability or dislocation.


4. Ultrasound Considerations for Newborns

  • Limitations: Ultrasound findings before 6 weeks of age can be unreliable due to ligamentous laxity in the early newborn period.

5. Radiographic Lines and Measurements in DDH

  • Hilgenreiner's Line B. Perkin's Line C. Shenton's Line

6. Center-Edge Angle of Wiberg

  • Definition: The angle between a vertical line (Perkins' line) and a line drawn from the lateral edge of the acetabulum to the center of the femoral head.
  • Normal Range: Greater than 10° in children between 6 and 13 years. This angle increases with age.
  • Significance: It is a useful measure of hip position in older children. A lower angle suggests under coverage of the femoral head, characteristic of hip dysplasia.

Option A, B & D: DDH is diagnosed with USG in which alpha angle is decreased and beta angle is increased.

Key takeaways

  • USGis used for screening of DDH
  • AI - In children older than 6 months, the AI should be less than 25°.
  • Alpha angle: Normal Range: Greater than 60° - Decreased in DDH.
  • Beta angle: Normal Range: Less than 55° - Increased in DDH.
  • CE angle of Wiberg - Normal Range: Greater than 10° in children between 6 and 13 years. This angle increases with age

choices.text: Seen in Salter Harris type III fractures in children
Seen in Salter Harris type II fractures in adults
Seen in Salter Harris type II fractures in children
Seen in Salter Harris type III fractures in adults

questions.text: Select the true statement regarding Thurston Holland sign:
questions.solution:
In SH type II fractures the epiphyseal fragment thus comprises all of the epiphysis and some portion of the peripheral metaphysis (the Thurston-Holland fragment or sign).


Salter-Harris Classification of Growth Plate Fractures

Salter and Harris classification: Epiphyseal injuries in children have been classified into 5 types based on their X-ray appearance. The higher the classification the more severe the injury.


Salter-Harris Classification Types:

  1. Type I (Slip)
    • Description: A fracture that occurs straight across the growth plate (physis) without involving the metaphysis or epiphysis.
    • Characteristics: The physis is separated or slipped, but the surrounding bone remains intact.
    • Prognosis: Generally, a good prognosis with proper treatment, as the growth plate remains largely undamaged.
  2. Type II (Above) (Option B,C)
    • Description: A fracture through the growth plate and metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis.
    • Characteristics: The most common type, it extends across the physis and into the metaphysis, creating a triangular fragment of the metaphysis.
    • Prognosis: Good, as the growth plate is still relatively unharmed; usually does not result in growth disturbances.
  3. Type III (Lower) (Option A,D)
    • Description: A fracture through the growth plate and epiphysis, sparing the metaphysis.
    • Characteristics: The fracture extends from the physis into the articular surface of the bone.
    • Prognosis: Can affect growth and joint function if not properly treated, as it involves the articular cartilage and growth plate.
  4. Type IV (Through)
    • Description: A fracture through the metaphysis, growth plate, and epiphysis.
    • Characteristics: The fracture passes vertically through all three elements, potentially damaging the growth plate and joint surface.
    • Prognosis: Risk of growth disturbance and joint dysfunction is higher; requires precise anatomical reduction to prevent complications.
  5. Type V (Rammed)
    • Description: A compression fracture of the growth plate.
    • Characteristics: The growth plate is crushed or compressed, often leading to growth arrest.
    • Prognosis: Poor, due to the significant damage to the growth plate; high risk of growth arrest and deformity.

Option A, C & D:

In Children SH type II fractures the epiphyseal fragment thus comprises all of the epiphysis and some portion of the peripheral metaphysis (the Thurston–Holland fragment or sign). Thus Option A, C & D Are wrong.

Key takeaways:

  1. In SH type II fractures the epiphyseal fragment thus comprises all of the epiphysis and some portion of the peripheral metaphysis (the Thurston-Holland fragment or sign).
  2. Mnemonic - SALTe R and its example

Slip (Type I) -SCFE

Above (Type II)-supracondylar humerus #

Lower (Type III)-tillaux #

Through (Type IV)-lateral condylar humerus#

Rammed (Type V)-crush injury

questions.text: A 6 year old girl presents with pain, swelling and deformity after falling on an outstretched hand. X Ray reveals supracondylar humerus fracture. All of these modalities can be used to treat such fractures except:
questions.solution:
(Option A): Nailing is preferred for diaphyseal (shaft) fractures and usually done after closed reduction.


Treatment of SCH Fractures in children

1. Undisplaced Fractures

  • Immobilization:
    • Use an above-elbow plaster slab. (Option B)
    • Position the elbow in 90° flexion.

2. Displaced Fractures

  • Treatment Methods:
    • a) Closed Reduction and Percutaneous K-Wire Fixation: (Option C)
      • Procedure:
        • Displaced fractures are usually reduced by closed reduction.
        • To prevent slippage, fixation with one or two K-wires is performed.
        • K-wires are inserted percutaneously under image intensifier guidance.
      • Alternative:
        • If an image intensifier is unavailable, careful monitoring of the fracture position in plaster is essential.
      • b) Open Reduction and K-Wire Fixation: (Option D)
        • Indications:
          • When closed methods fail to achieve or maintain proper positioning.
          • If the fracture displaced after reduction.
          • Used as a first-line treatment for some open fractures.
          • Necessary for exploration of the brachial artery if there is suspected injury.
        • Procedure:
          • Involves surgical intervention to directly visualize and correct the fracture.
          • K-wires are used for fixation to stabilize the fracture.
          • Refer to Figure 14.9 for illustrative details.
        • c) Continuous Traction:
          • Indications:
            • Employed in cases with late presentation involving excessive swelling or severe wounds around the elbow.
          • Purpose:
            • To manage and stabilize the fracture while addressing complications associated with swelling or wound issues.

Option B, C & D: Closed reduction and cast application, Closed reduction and pinning and Open reduction and pinning all three are management options for SCH Fractures.

Key takeaways

  • Gartland classification is used to classify SCH fractures in children
  • Classical clinical sign is S sign of the arm and elbow
  • Most common injury in children following fall on an out-stretched hand is SCH fractures.
  • If undergoes mal-union; SCH fractures can cause gun stock deformity.

choices.text: Pain is usually mild but may radiate to anterior thigh/knee
Limitation of internal rotation and abduction movements
Xray shows collapse and sclerosis in femur head epiphysis
Surgical osteotomy should be done in this case

questions.text: A 7 yr old boy presents with mild pain and limping in right hip. He is not able to swing the leg outwards and away from the body while trying to ride a bicycle. MRI reveals signs of early Perthes disease. Select false statements.
questions.solution:
Perthes Disease

Demographics

  • Common Age Group: Boys aged 5-10 years.

Clinical Presentation

  • Symptoms:
    • Pain in the hip, often radiating to the knee. (Option A)
    • Limping or hip stiffness.
  • Examination Findings:
    • Minimal findings may include: (Option B)
      • Limitation of hip abduction.
      • Reduced internal rotation.
      • Shortening of the affected limb.

Radiological Findings

  • Imaging Characteristics:
    • Collapse and sclerosis of the epiphysis of the femoral head. (Option C)
    • Increased hip joint space.

Treatment

  • Primary Goals:
    • Relieve pain.
    • Restore hip movements.
    • Prevent further deformity of the femoral head.
  • Treatment Methods:
    • Non-Surgical:
      • Use of casts and braces.
      • Offloading with crutches.
    • Surgical:
      • Reserved for patients older than 8 years or in cases with poor prognostic signs. (Option D)
      • Includes osteotomies to correct or prevent further damage.

Option A, C & D: Pain is usually mild but may radiate to anterior thigh/knee, Limitation of internal rotation and abduction movements and Xray shows collapse and sclerosis in femur head epiphysis all three are correct statements.

Key takeaways:

Perthes disease is managed mostly with cast and braces. Surgical management is Reserved for patients older than 8 years or in cases with poor prognostic signs. It Includes osteotomies to correct or prevent further damage.

choices.text: Pronation of forearm and extension of elbow
Supination of forearm and flexion of elbow

questions.text: A couple presents with a 3 yr old girl who has been restless and crying for a while and not using the left upper limb after her elder brother pulled her by holding her hands while playing. X Ray is normal. What maneuver has to be done that possibly will resolve the issue?
questions.solution:
Pulled Elbow

  • Description:
    • A condition commonly seen in children aged 2-5 years.
    • The head of the radius is partially pulled out of the annular ligament, typically when a child is lifted by the wrist.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Symptoms:
      • Immediate crying upon injury.
      • Inability to move the affected limb.
      • Forearm positioned in pronation.
    • X-ray Findings:
      • The subluxated head is not visible on X-ray due to its cartilaginous nature.
      • X-rays are used to rule out other bony injuries.
    • Treatment:
      • Reduction Procedure:
        • Fully supinate the forearm.
        • Flex the elbow.
        • Apply direct pressure over the head of the radius.
        • A sudden click is often heard or felt as the head returns to its proper place.
      • Outcome:
        • The child typically becomes comfortable and resumes normal elbow movement almost immediately.

Option A, B & D: Reduction Procedure Involves Supination and Flexion

Options Containing Pronation and Extension are Wrong.

Key takeaways

  • The head of the radius is partially pulled out of the annular ligament, typically when a child is lifted by the wrist.
  • Pulled elbow is always a clinical diagnosis. X Ray is usually normal.
  • Spontaneous resolution of symptoms is classical after reduction by Supination and Flexion of Elbow.

questions.text: A classical clinical sign of grossly displaced supracondylar humerus fractures in children is:
questions.solution:
In type III SCH fractures, gross displacement of the elbow is evident leading to S shaped deformity as seen in the image.

Pathoanatomy of Supracondylar Humerus Fracture

  • Location: Transverse fracture line through the distal metaphysis of the humerus, just above the condyles.

Types:

  1. Extension Type:
    • Description: The distal fragment is tilted backwards (extended) in relation to the proximal fragment.
    • Prevalence: More common of the two types.
  2. Flexion Type:
    • Description: The distal fragment is tilted forwards (flexed) in relation to the proximal fragment.
    • Prevalence: Less common.

Displacements:

  • Posterior or Backward Shift: Distal fragment shifts posteriorly.
  • Posterior or Backward Tilt: Distal fragment tilts backwards.
  • Proximal Shift: Distal fragment moves proximally.
  • Medial or Lateral Shift: Distal fragment shifts medially or laterally.
  • Medial Tilt: Distal fragment tilts medially.
  • Internal Rotation: Distal fragment rotates internally.
  • Option A, B & C: The S-shaped configuration is created by the anterior prominence of the proximal fragment's spike and extension of the distal fragment. It's not C, U or J Shaped so Option A, B & C are wrong.

Key takeaway:

  • In type III SCH fractures, gross displacement of the elbow is evident leading to S shaped deformity.
  • Deformity in malunited SCH fractures is called gun stock deformity.

choices.text: Exploration and vascular repair by vascular surgeon

questions.text: An 11 yr old boy presents with grossly displaced SCH fracture and absent pulse or perfusion in the emergency room. Gentle traction for sometime followed by CRIF using pins in the operating room restores the perfusion but the pulse is still absent (pulseless perfused hand). What will be the next step?
questions.solution:
The management plan for pulseless SCH fractures is as follows


Management of Pulseless Supracondylar Humerus Fracture (SCH Fx)

1. Assessment and Admission:

  • Initial Step: Admit the patient and closely observe the condition of the limb. In the Emergency Department (ED), gentle traction and flexing the elbow to 30-45 degrees are applied to stabilize the fracture initially.
  • Apply plaster if undisplaced or pin in OR if displaced

2. Evaluation of Perfusion and Pulses:

  • Well Perfused with Good Pulse:
    • Management: Continue monitoring and assess for any changes. No immediate intervention is required if the pulse is strong and the limb is well-perfused.
  • Well Perfused with No Pulse:
    • Management: Although the limb is well-perfused, the absence of a pulse requires further evaluation. Admit the patient and do continuous pulse and perfusion monitoring.
  • Poorly Perfused with No Pulse:
    • Management: Immediate action is required. Please consult with a vascular specialist to assess for any potential vascular injuries and explore their presence. Do ORIF for fracture and vascular repair if necessary.

Option B: Exploration and vascular repair by vascular surgeon is done if Poor perfusion symptoms develop in pulseless syndrome.

Option C: Re-apply traction and CRIF again is not required. Observation and further evaluation of pulse is the next step in management.

Option D: Re-apply traction and ORIF Is done in poor perfusion patients.

Key takeaways:

Pulseless Supracondylar Humerus Fracture is managed with Observation & Evaluation. If Poor Perfusion symptoms develop immediate action and Consulting Vascular surgeon required.

choices.text: Distal radius is the commonest site

questions.text: Torus fractures: Select the false statement:
questions.solution:
Classification:

  • Torus Fractures
    • Description:Axial compression injuries.
    • Site of Cortical Failure:Transition from metaphysis to diaphysis.
    • Characteristics:
      • Inherently stable due to compression mode of failure.
      • Stabilized by the intact surrounding periosteum.
      • Rarely may extend into the physis, risking growth impairment.
  • Incomplete or Greenstick Fractures
    • Description:Occur with a combination of compressive, tensile, and rotatory forces.
    • Characteristics:
      • Results in complete failure of one cortex and plastic deformation of the other cortex.
      • Commonly caused by combined extension and supination forces.
      • Typically leads to tensile failure of the volar cortex and dorsal compression injury.
      • The degree of force affects plastic deformation, dorsal comminution, and fracture angulation/rotation.
  • Complete Fractures
    • Description:Occur with disruption of both the volar and dorsal cortices.
    • Characteristics:
      • Length may be maintained with apposition of the proximal and distal fragments.
      • Frequently, the distal fragment lies proximal and dorsal to the proximal fragment, resulting in bayonet apposition.

Option A, C and D:

Torus fracture is a unicortical fracture typically seen in the metaphyseal region in children. Distal radius is the commonest site.

Key takeaways:

Torus Fracture

  • Unicortical
  • Metaphysical
  • Distal radial fractures in children.

choices.text: Order of correction in Ponseti's method is - cavus, adductus, varus, equinus
Total duration of treatment by Kite's method is 5-6 weeks
Kite method is rarely used because of the inability of others to match his results
Casts are changed every week in Ponseti technique

questions.text: Select the false statement in view of Kite's and Ponseti's method of correction of CTEV:
questions.solution:
Clubfoot Treatment Methods

Kite Method:

  • Principle: Forefoot should be slightly overcorrected into a mild flatfoot position before correcting equinus.
  • Historical Context: Kite's method was once popular but is now rarely used due to:
    • Inconsistent Results: Difficulty replicating Kite's results. (Option C)
    • Lengthy Treatment: Requires 26 to 49 weeks of casting. (Option B)
  • Current Status:Outdated due to the success of more modern methods.

Ponseti's Philosophy of Clubfoot Treatment

Understanding Pathoanatomy:

  • Key Insight: The deformity involves internal rotation (adduction) of the calcaneo-cuboid-navicular complex beneath the plantarflexed talus.
  • Correction Approach:
    • Manual Correction: Apply thumb pressure over the talar head, not the calcaneo-cuboid joint.
    • Objective: Externally rotate the calcaneo-cuboid-navicular complex under the talar head by stretching tight structures.

Treatment Protocol:

  1. Initiation:
    • Timing: Begin treatment within the 1st week of life.
  2. Deformity Correction Sequence: (Option A)
    • Cavus: Correct first.
    • Adduction: Address next.
    • Varus: Correct after adduction.
    • Equinus: Correct last.
  3. Casting:
    • Procedure: After each manipulation, apply an above-knee plaster of Paris (POP) cast.
    • Frequency: Change casts every 5-7 days with total duration being 5-6 weeks. (Option D)
    • Duration: Typically, all components of the deformity are corrected within 6 weeks.
  4. Residual Equinus:
    • Treatment: Often remains undercorrected.
    • Management: Treat with percutaneous tenotomy of the tendoachilles.
    • Outcome: The cut tendoachilles regenerates spontaneously.

Option A, C & D: All three are correct statements.

Option B: Total duration of treatment by Kite's method is 24-48 weeks thus option b is false.

Key takeaways:

Order of correction in CTEV - Mnemonic - CAVE:

  • C: Cavus
  • A: Adductus
  • V: Varus
  • E: Equinus

questions.text: Identify the surgery shown in the image that is used to treat CTEV.
questions.solution:
1. Postero-medial Soft Tissue Release (PMSTR)
This procedure involves releasing tight soft tissues on the posterior and medial sides of the foot. It is typically performed on younger children under the age of 3. In older children, additional bony procedures may be needed.

2. Limited Soft Tissue Release

Specific releases are done based on the component of the deformity:

  • Posterior release for equinus
  • Medial release for adduction
  • Plantar release for cavus
    This approach is used when the foot is partially corrected after conservative treatment.

3. Tendon Transfers

The tibialis anterior is transferred to the outer side of the foot to counteract the weak peroneal muscles. This method is suitable for children over 5 years of age.

4. Dwyer's Osteotomy (Option B)

An open-wedge osteotomy of the calcaneum is performed to correct heel varus. It is generally carried out in children aged 3 years and older.

5. Dilwyn Evans Procedure (Option A)

This technique combines soft tissue release with calcaneo-cuboid fusion to correct neglected or recurrent clubfoot. It is recommended for children aged 4-8 years.

6. Wedge Tarsectomy (Option C)

A wedge of bone is removed from the mid-tarsal area to correct the deformity. This procedure is usually performed on children aged 8-11 years with neglected clubfeet.

7. Triple Arthrodesis (Option D)

Fusion of the subtalar, calcaneo-cuboid, and talo-navicular joints is performed, typically in children over 12 years of age. This procedure addresses deformities when the bones have matured.

8. Ilizarov's Technique

Utilizes an external fixator for gradual correction of deformities, which is maintained with plaster casts. This method is applied for neglected or recurrent clubfeet.

9. JESS Fixation

A simplified technique based on Ilizarov's principles, developed by Dr. B.B. Joshi. It is used for similar indications as Ilizarov's technique.

Key takeaways:

Dwyer's osteotomy: This is an open-wedge osteotomy of the calcaneus, performed in order to correct varus of the heel. Minimum age at which this operation can be performed is 3 years, as prior to this the calcaneum is mainly cartilaginous. Some prefer a closed-wedge osteotomy on the lateral side.

choices.text: Schamm's loss of dense triangular appearance in infero-medial neck

questions.text: All of the following are true about slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) except:
questions.solution:
Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis (SCFE)

Overview:
SCFE is a condition where the upper femoral epiphysis slips at the growth plate, typically in a postero-medial direction, resulting in coxa vara. The slip usually occurs gradually, though it can be sudden.

Causes:
The exact cause is unknown, but it is thought to involve trauma in the presence of an underlying abnormality. It is more common in:

  • Obese and sexually underdeveloped children
  • Tall, thin children with normal sexual development

Clinical Features:

  • Age: Common between 12-14 years of age, typically during puberty.
  • Sex: More frequent in boys.
  • Side: Affects both sides in 30% of cases.
  • Trauma: A history of trauma may be present in some cases.
  • Endocrine Abnormalities: More common in children with endocrine issues.

Symptoms:

  • Pain in the groin radiating to the thigh and knee.
  • Early limp that becomes constant.
  • Symptoms may initially be mistaken for a sprain.

Examination Findings:

  • Leg is externally rotated and may be 1-2 cm short.
  • Limited hip movements: restricted abduction and internal rotation, with increased adduction and external rotation.
  • During hip flexion, the knee may move towards the ipsilateral axilla.
  • Muscle bulk may be reduced.
  • Positive Trendelenburg's sign.

Radiological Features:

  • AP View: Displacement of the growth plate towards the metaphyseal side; Trethowan's sign (the line along the superior surface of the neck remains superior to the head).
  • Steel's metaphyseal blanch sign and Scham's loss of dense triangular appearance of inferomedial articular neck is seen in SCFE.
  • Lateral View: Head is angulated on the neck, detectable early.

Treatment:

  • Acute Slip: Closed reduction and pinning, similar to treatment for a femoral neck fracture.
  • Gradual Slip:
    • For slips less than 1/3 of the femoral neck diameter: Internal fixation in situ.
    • For slips greater than 1/3: Corrective osteotomy at the intertrochanteric region.
  • Unilateral Cases: Prophylactic pinning of the unaffected side is recommended due to a 30% chance of bilateral involvement.

Option A&C:

Steel's metaphyseal blanch sign and Scham's loss of dense triangular appearance of inferomedial articular neck is seen in SCFE.

Option B: In infantile coxa vara, neck-shaft angle is reduced.

Option D: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis is a disease of adolescence, commonly associated with endocrine disorders.

Key takeaways:

SCFE:

  • Trethowan sign
  • Steel's metaphyseal blanch sign and Scham's loss of dense triangular appearance
  • A/w Endocrine disorders

choices.text: Scham's loss of dense triangular appearance in infero-medial neck

questions.text: Identify the characteristic sign shown in the image that is seen in SCFE:
questions.solution:
Option C: Trethowan's sign seen in SCFE

On AP view: The growth plate is displaced towards the metaphyseal side. A line drawn along the superior surface of the neck remains superior to the head unlike in a normal hip where it passes bisecting the head - Trethowan's sign

SCFE:

Clinical Features:

  • Age: Common between 12-14 years of age, typically during puberty.
  • Sex: More frequent in boys.
  • Side: Affects both sides in 30% of cases.
  • Trauma: A history of trauma may be present in some cases.
  • Endocrine Abnormalities: More common in children with endocrine issues.

Symptoms:

  • Pain in the groin radiating to the thigh and knee.
  • Early limp that becomes constant.
  • Symptoms may initially be mistaken for a sprain.

Examination Findings:

  • Leg is externally rotated and may be 1-2 cm short.
  • Limited hip movements: restricted abduction and internal rotation, with increased adduction and external rotation.
  • During hip flexion, the knee may move towards the ipsilateral axilla.
  • Muscle bulk may be reduced.
  • Positive Trendelenburg's sign.

Option A: Steel's blach sign seen in SCFE


Option B: Scham sign seen in SCFE


Option D: Gage sign which is seen in Perthes disease

Key takeaway:

On AP view: The growth plate is displaced towards the metaphyseal side. A line drawn along the superior surface of the neck remains superior to the head unlike in a normal hip where it passes bisecting the head - Trethowan's sign

questions.text: Which anatomical structure is used as a fulcrum to correct adduction of the calcaneo-cuboid-navicular complex in child with CTEV in Ponseti's method?
questions.solution:
Option A and D: Body of talus and navicular are of no significance in applying cast for CTEV correction.

Option B: Head to talus is used as fulcrum to correct deformities in Ponseti's method

Option C: Calcano-cuboid joint was used in Kite's method as fulcrum.

Key takeaway:

According to Ponsetti, the calcaneo-cuboid-navicular complex is internally rotated (adducted) under the plantar-flexed talus, Hence, the deformity can be corrected by bringing the complex back under the talus by gradually stretching the tight structures. This is done by putting thumb pressure over the talus head (and not over calcaneo-cuboid joint as in Kite's method).

questions.text: A 5 yr child presents with neglected DDH. After doing all the examinations and tests the surgeon decides to do surgical osteotomy and open reduction of the hip. All of these are possible osteotomy options for this case except:
questions.solution:
Surgical Osteotomies in DDH:

  1. Salter's Osteotomy (Option D)
    • Type: Iliac bone osteotomy above the acetabulum.
    • Procedure: The acetabular roof is rotated with the pubic symphysis as the fulcrum.
    • Purpose: Increases horizontal coverage of the femoral head by the acetabulum.
  2. Chiari's Pelvic Displacement Osteotomy (Option B)
    • Type: Transverse osteotomy of the iliac bone above the acetabulum.
    • Procedure: The lower fragment (with the acetabulum) is displaced medially, allowing the upper fragment to add depth to the acetabulum.
    • Purpose: Enhances acetabular depth and coverage of the femoral head.
  3. Pemberton's Pericapsular Osteotomy (Option A)
    • Type: Curved osteotomy near the acetabulum.
    • Procedure: The acetabular roof is deflected downwards over the femoral head, with the triradiate cartilage as the fulcrum.
    • Purpose: Improves coverage of the femoral head by changing the angle of the acetabulum.

Option C: Pauwels osteotomy is used for old neglected/ non united/ malunited neck of femur fractures and not DDH.

Key takeaways :

Pauwels Osteotomy:

  • Type: Valgus osteotomy at the level of the lesser trochanter.
  • Procedure: Creates a valgus effect at the fracture site, converting shearing forces into compression forces, which aids in fracture healing.
  • Fixation: Done using a double-angle blade plate.
  • Technical difficulty: It is a technically demanding

choices.text: Mutation in FGFR2 gene is noted in most cases
There is a quantitative cartilage defect noted

questions.solution:
Achondroplasia is a genetic disorder that results in disproportionate dwarfism (Option A) due to abnormal bone growth, especially affecting the long bones. It follows an autosomal dominant inheritance (Option B), though many cases arise from new gene mutations.

Key Features:

  • Physical Characteristics: Short limbs with a relatively normal trunk, large skull, prominent forehead, and flat nose. Hands have short, stubby fingers.
  • Normal Intelligence: Cognitive abilities are unaffected.
  • Complications: Possible spinal canal stenosis, increased lumbar lordosis, and joint mobility issues.
  • Diagnosis: Based on physical traits, X-rays, and genetic testing.
  • Management: No cure, but physical therapy, surgical interventions, and supportive care help manage symptoms. Individuals typically lead normal lives.

Option A: Achondroplasia is the most common form of disproportionate short limbed dwarfism.

Option B: Achondroplasia is autosomal dominant inheritance.

Option C: FGFR2 gene mutation is associated with craniosynostosis.

Option D: Achondroplasia is a Quantitative, not qualitative, cartilage defect.

Key takeaways:

  • Achondroplasia is the most common form of disproportionate short limbed dwarfism.
  • Autosomal dominant condition; 80% of cases caused by a spontaneous mutation in the fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 (FGFR3)
  • Achondroplasia is categorized as a Quantitative physeal dysplasia (cartilaginous proliferative zone)
